docs.abstract: Fiona Havers letter about May 21 article says television watching among infants and toddlers has been linked to increases in attention problems and obesity
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The article mentions that public health advocates are likely to oppose BabyFirst. The article does not elaborate however. Television viewing in small children is far from innocuous. Numerous studies have linked television watching among infants and toddlers to increases in attention problems and obesity. The Times should address these issues rather than tout this ridiculous channel. Fiona Havers Seattle
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     The article mentions that public health advocates are likely to oppose BabyFirst. The article does not elaborate however. Television viewing in small children is far from innocuous. Numerous studies have linked television watching...

docs.lead_paragraph: The discovery of genes that seem to influence everything from obesity to addiction is changing the way people feel about themselves, The Times's Amy Harmon reports.

byline.original: By MARCELLA RUNELL and BRIDGET ANDERSON

docs.abstract: In this lesson, students explore the concepts and content necessary to write narrative feature articles and then develop their own such articles.
docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.snippet: In this lesson, students explore the concepts and content necessary to write narrative feature articles and then develop their own such articles.
